6.3.17  8:47 pm   If somebody was born and raised in a cave, in complete isolation from all society and technology since birth, but in their cave there was a grand piano (that they've had since birth)... Do you think that person would have an inclination to play and make music (in some form) on that piano without any knowledge of the existence or even the concept of music? Or would they just think "this thing makes strange noises when I hit these little black and white rectangles... that's weird" and that would be the end of it?

6.3.17  6:15 pm   I know you already have answered a few questions on here about defining music, and I like your thoughts on it. Really, it doesn't matter what the definition of music is. It has no clear definition, and yet it still exists, people make it and people listen to it and buy it. There's lots of different ways people have defined music.. some have given really simplified answers. Edgard Varese has one of the most famous definitions of music as being "organized sound." Frank Zappa said "a composer is a guy who goes around forcing his will on unsuspecting air molecules, often with the assistance of unsuspecting musicians." Barney Childs' definition is that "A piece of music is simply a chunk of time you are paying attention to with your ears." Others have given definitions that are more abstract, like Beethoven ("Music is the one incorporeal entrance into the higher world of knowledge which comprehends mankind but which mankind cannot comprehend"). You said "the onl y way i really know of to define it is by making some of it, or finding some of it to listen to. then you can go, "ah, that's music. i think"" .... But if music is in the eye (or ear) of the beholder... where does that leave the composer/creator/performer? If someone makes something that they personally intended to be music, then shouldn't it music rather or not you or I (or any other listener) interprets it as such?

6.3.17  2:21 pm   So on Instagram you posted a picture of a rotated, purple, California shaped outline against a black background. The picture implies to many of your fans, including me, that you have started work on a music video for your most recent song, "In California". However, on the 6.1.17 11:21 pm question you said "In California" would not be getting a video. And on the 6.2.17 6:16 am question you were asked about the topic of the next video to which you replied, "what video". So these questions imply to your fans that you aren't making a video at all and are starting on the next song project. But that still leaves the question: If you're not making a video then what was the Instagram photo from? (Sorry, btw, if I am completely off about all of this and you have been repeating the answer throughout my question.)

6.3.17  11:32 am   Hey bill, one thing I love about you is you do your own thing with no regards as to what anyone thinks, but judging by recent answers it looks like it's starting to affect you.

      When people feel entitled for things from you, ads/no ads, spotify, free content, capital letters etc... I understand this question page is your survival strategy but as a humble observer from afar, it looks like this page is bringing more negativity than you deserve. You don't owe us anything, and if you need to take a break from answering questions and focus on your art, it would be more than reasonable. HoJ and HOTEWIG only made you more famous, and the more famous you get, the more you will receive negativity like that. If you don't properly know how to deal with it now, it might just get worse.

      With all that being said, do you think your survival strategy should change or remain intact?

6.3.17  2:47 am   when i listen to "school" i think it's a deep statement on human nature, and more specifically, ignorance in a depressing way. school is a metaphor for knowledge in general. the lines "i don't wanna go to school, because i'm stupid, i don't want nobody tellin me what to do or how to get through this" to me seem like a statement on how people prefer to figure out life on their own way. they think they can wing it, make it up as they go, improvise. the next lines "i don't want nobody tellin me how to think, tellin me how to sing, tellin me how to do everything" really emphasize this point. but in the next lines, the true intentions behind the narrator's willful ignorance is revealed. "i don't wanna be afraid, of criminals, i don't wanna be afraid, of dangerous politicians" is the climax of the story. he doesn't want to expose himself to the harsh realities of the "real world", which could also be why the song uses the metaphor "school", since students are ofte n warned about said "real world". "i don't wanna be afraid of you, or of me, or the truth" further this point, because scariness is everywhere, and we all wish it wasn't like that, but we know deep inside of us that it is. the last lines, "said that girl made me feel blue, cause she told me I should stay in school, said that girl made me feel blue, don't go to school" is a nice closer, in which the narrator turns his nose to people telling him to "stay informed" or even perhaps "grow up", because all it does is make people sad. do you think this analysis is appropriate? or am i overthinking just a really catchy, danceable song? love your videos, ants just crawled out of my laptop.
